intro: Cochlearia variifolia, commonly known as the variable cochlearia, is a flowering plant native to the British Isles and parts of northern Europe. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, also known as the mustard family, and is characterized by its small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in coastal areas or on limestone cliffs. It has basal leaves that are usually lobed or toothed, and its flowering period occurs from late spring to early summer. Cochlearia variifolia is a short-lived perennial that is sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value.
